content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Concisely written. I think reverse would be the hardest mode, but it still should not take too long to figure out.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great way to learn 2 dimensional arrays

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is simple but yet very nice challenge for a clash of code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good job !

"The middle of the shape" seems a bit vague to me. Looking at the test cases I first thought it was about averaging all points inside the grid, but then I looked at the code and there it was the middle of the bounding box. The test cases work either of these ways, but imo there should be some clarification in the text.

I was trying to avoid telling people how to code the calculation (and sidestep any arguments about the spelling of "centre"!), but you're right.

I've added
"* For this Clash, the middle of the shape is the centre of the minimum bounding box of all the non-empty grid squares. You don't need to average all the coordinates or find the centre of gravity."

If the average is not an intended solution then add a test that doesn't allow it.
Right now two logically different solutions fit all of the test cases and it's not good if it's in reverse. You force good players that figured out both solutions to wonder which solution is an intended one and if validators would work for both solutions or not.
Not that big of a deal but it's better to not force players to take a leap of faith.

UPD: Also, you can just take coordinates of the first and the last '#' that you encounter and take an average.
Just add some non-symmetric shapes and it'll fix everything.
